passage_list.text:
Unlike many other Disney classics, from Cinderella to Frozen, this fright fest is not based on a fairy tale. It was adapted from Bambi: A Life in the Woods, a 1922 novel by the Austro-Hungarian writer and critic Felix Salten. The book rendered Salten famous; the movie, which altered and overshadowed its source material, rendered him virtually unknown. And it rendered the original Bambi obscure, too, even though it had previously been both widely acclaimed and passionately reviled. The English-language version, as translated in 1928 by the soon to be Soviet spy Whittaker Chambers, was enormously popular, earning rave reviews and selling 650,000 copies in the dozen-plus years before the film came out. The original version, meanwhile, was banned and burned in Nazi Germany, where it was regarded as a parable about the treatment of Jews in Europe.

As that suggests, Bambi the book is even darker than Bambi the movie. Until now, English-language readers had to rely on the Chambers translation—which, thanks to a controversial copyright ruling, has been the only one available for almost a century. This year, however, Bambi: A Life in the Woods has entered the public domain, and the Chambers version has been joined by a new one: The Original Bambi: The Story of a Life in the Forest (Princeton), translated by Jack Zipes, with wonderful black-and-white illustrations by Alenka Sottler. Zipes, a professor emeritus of German and comparative literature at the University of Minnesota, who has also translated the fairy tales of the Brothers Grimm, maintains in his introduction that Chambers got Bambi almost as wrong as Disney did. Which raises two questions: How exactly did a tale about the life of a fawn become so contentious, and what is it really about?

Felix Salten was an unlikely figure to write Bambi, since he was an ardent hunter who, by his own estimate, shot and killed more than two hundred deer. He was also an unlikely figure to write a parable about Jewish persecution, since, even after the book burnings, he promoted a policy of appeasement toward Nazi Germany. And he was an unlikely figure to write one of the most famous children’s stories of the twentieth century, since he wrote one of its most infamous works of child pornography.

These contradictions are nicely encapsulated by Beverley Driver Eddy in her biography Felix Salten: Man of Many Faces. Born Siegmund Salzmann in Hungary in 1869, Salten was just three weeks old when his family moved to Vienna—a newly desirable destination for Jews because Austria had lately granted them full citizenship. His father was a descendant of generations of rabbis who shook off his religious roots in favor of a broad-minded humanism; he was also a hopelessly inept businessman who soon plunged the family into poverty. To help pay the bills, Salten started working for an insurance company in his teens, around the same time that he began submitting poetry and literary criticism to local newspapers and journals. Eventually, he began meeting other writers and creative types at a café called the Griensteidl, across the street from the national theater. These were the fin-de-siècle artists collectively known as Young Vienna, whose members included Arthur Schnitzler, Arnold Schoenberg, Stefan Zweig, and a writer who later repudiated the group, Karl Kraus.

Salten was, in his youth, both literally and literarily promiscuous. He openly conducted many affairs—with chambermaids, operetta singers, actresses, a prominent socialist activist, and, serially or simultaneously, several women with whom other members of Young Vienna were having dalliances as well. In time, he married and settled down, but all his life he wrote anything he could get paid to write: book reviews, theater reviews, art criticism, essays, plays, poems, novels, a book-length advertisement for a carpet company disguised as reportage, travel guides, librettos, forewords, afterwords, film scripts. His detractors regarded this torrent as evidence of hackery, but it was more straightforwardly evidence of necessity; almost alone among the members of Young Vienna, he was driven by the need to make a living.

Yet, like his father, Salten could be reckless with money. Anxious to seem like an insider, he insisted on eating, drinking, dressing, and travelling in the manner of his wealthier peers, with the result that he was constantly accruing debts, some of which he dispatched in dodgy ways—for instance, by “borrowing” and then selling a friend’s expensive books. And he could be reckless in other respects, too. Inclined to be touchy, either by temperament or because he felt the need to prove himself, he spent much of his young life fomenting disputes (he once walked into the Griensteidl and slapped Kraus in the face after the latter criticized him in print), then resolving them via lawsuits or duels. Both his personal judgment and his critical judgment could be impulsive and errant; in his thirties, he borrowed prodigiously to produce a modernist cabaret, of the kind that was all the rage in Berlin, only to see it become a critical and financial catastrophe.

The production that brought Salten the most infamy, however, did not bear his name: Josefine Mutzenbacher; or, The Story of a Viennese Whore, as Told by Herself. Published anonymously in Vienna in 1906, it has been continuously in print since then, in both German and English, and has sold some three million copies. Despite the subtitle, no one ever seems to have entertained the possibility that it was written by a prostitute, or even by a woman. In Salten’s lifetime, nearly everyone thought he wrote it, except for those who liked him too much to believe he could produce something so filthy and those who hated him too much to believe he could produce something so well written. Salten himself twice claimed not to have been responsible for it but otherwise was silent or coy on the subject. These days, everyone from academics to the Austrian government regards him as the undisputed author of the book.

Written in the tradition of the ribald female memoir, à la Fanny Hill, Josefine Mutzenbacher recounts the sexual adventures of the title character beginning when she is five years old, and continuing after her turn to prostitution in her early teens, following the death of her mother. Today, what is most shocking about the book is Josefine’s youth. At the time, however, most of the scandal concerned her unapologetic embrace of her career, which she both enjoyed and credited with lifting her out of poverty, educating her, and introducing her to a world far wider than the impoverished Vienna suburbs where she (like Salten) grew up.

Perhaps inevitably, scholars have tried to draw parallels between Josefine Mutzenbacher and Bambi. Both title characters lose their mothers while still in their youth; both books introduce readers in detail to urban borderlands—the poor suburbs, the flophouses, the forests—about which most proper Viennese were largely ignorant. Still, for the most part, such comparisons seem strained. Josefine Mutzenbacher occupies much the same place in the Salten oeuvre as his homage to carpets: the one that lies at the intersection of ambition, graphomania, and penury.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the main subject of the passage?

options.A: The process of adapting a classic novel into a film.
options.B: The evolution and controversy surrounding the translations and reception of a well-known novel.
options.C: The technical aspects of film production and animation.
options.D: The historical banning of literature in Nazi Germany.

questions.explanation: The passage centers on how the novel 'Bambi: A Life in the Woods' has been transformed over time—its adaptation into film, the varied translations, and its controversial reception—which is best captured by option B.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on identifying the central subject by noting the recurring themes and details provided in the text.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of mentioning the different translations and public domain status in the passage?

options.A: To criticize the original translator for inaccuracies.
options.B: To illustrate how translation and legal rulings can reshape a work’s cultural impact.
options.C: To highlight the technical challenges of literary translation.

questions.explanation: The passage uses the discussion of translations and public domain status to show how legal and cultural shifts can alter a work’s reception and legacy, making option B the most accurate.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When examining text structure, consider how specific details serve the overall argument or purpose of the passage.

questions.question: Based on the passage, what can be inferred about Felix Salten’s approach to writing?

options.A: He prioritized artistic expression over commercial success.
options.B: He was driven by financial necessity despite personal contradictions.
options.C: He exclusively targeted a niche audience interested in controversial subjects.
options.D: He avoided addressing sensitive social issues in his work.

questions.explanation: The passage implies that although Salten produced work that was both controversial and groundbreaking, his varied output was largely motivated by the need to earn a living, pointing to option B.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for clues in the text that reveal underlying motivations, even if they are not stated directly.

questions.question: How do the biographical details in the passage function within the overall narrative?

options.A: They explain the reasons behind his later financial struggles.
options.B: They provide cultural and social context that helped shape his literary career.
options.C: They diminish the significance of his controversial works.
options.D: They serve as a critique of early 20th-century European politics.

questions.explanation: The inclusion of biographical details offers insight into the social and cultural environment that influenced Salten’s work, making option B the best choice.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When synthesizing information, consider how background details contribute to a deeper understanding of an author's motivations and context.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the tone of the final section of the passage?
questions.explanation: The final section uses pointed language and a measured critique to highlight Salten’s controversial lifestyle and work, resulting in a tone that is both ironic and critical.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay attention to diction and stylistic choices to discern the tone and attitude of the writer.

questions.question: Which detail from the passage best supports the idea that Salten's personal life was as contentious as his literary output?

options.A: His association with the Young Vienna circle.
options.B: His involvement in frequent financial disputes and even duels.
options.C: His prolific work in various literary genres.

questions.explanation: The passage specifically mentions his tendency to engage in disputes, lawsuits, and duels, which underscores the contentious nature of his personal life alongside his work.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When answering evidence-based questions, pinpoint the details that most directly illustrate the main idea or argument.

questions.question: In the context of the passage, the term 'graphomania' most nearly means:

options.B: A tendency to commit financial fraud

questions.explanation: The context in which 'graphomania' is used refers to an excessive, almost compulsive, love for writing, which aligns with option A.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Examine the surrounding context for clues about the meaning of uncommon words or phrases.

questions.question: Which of the following sentences from the passage best illustrates the use of parallel structure?

options.A: He openly conducted many affairs—with chambermaids, operetta singers, actresses, a prominent socialist activist, and, serially or simultaneously, several women with whom other members of Young Vienna were having dalliances as well.
options.B: His detractors regarded this torrent as evidence of hackery, but it was more straightforwardly evidence of necessity.
options.C: Salten was, in his youth, both literally and literarily promiscuous.
options.D: Anxious to seem like an insider, he insisted on eating, drinking, dressing, and travelling in the manner of his wealthier peers.

questions.explanation: Option D presents a series of actions—eating, drinking, dressing, and travelling—in a parallel structure that enhances the rhythm and clarity of the sentence.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for lists or sequences in sentences; parallel structures often provide a clear and effective way to present multiple ideas.

questions.question: How does the author transition between the discussion of Salten's personal life and his professional legacy?

options.A: By contrasting his creative output with his personal indiscretions.
options.C: By listing the various genres he wrote in.
options.D: By recounting his early childhood experiences.

questions.explanation: The author shifts smoothly from describing Salten’s controversial personal behavior to examining the impact of his professional work, using contrast to highlight the duality of his legacy.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Notice how transitional phrases and contrasts are used to link disparate ideas in a coherent narrative.

questions.question: What can be inferred about the impact of Salten's work 'Josefine Mutzenbacher' based on the passage?

options.A: It was largely ignored by contemporary audiences.
options.B: It contributed significantly to his notorious reputation despite his denials.
options.C: It was universally acclaimed as a literary masterpiece.
options.D: It elevated his standing among academic critics.

questions.explanation: The passage details how the work, despite the controversy surrounding its authorship and content, has been continuously in print and remains a key factor in Salten's notorious legacy, supporting option B.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use inference questions to connect explicit details with their broader implications about an author's impact or reputation.

scoring_guidelines.800_level_performance: Students scoring at this level demonstrate mastery of all tested skills, including advanced analysis, synthesis, and reasoning, effectively supporting their answers with textual evidence.
scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may occasionally struggle with higher-level analysis and synthesis, sometimes missing subtle textual clues.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, requiring students to infer deeper meanings, analyze complex structures, and understand nuanced vocabulary in context.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess a solid understanding of the text, including its structure, purpose, and context, while requiring students to integrate details effectively.
explanation_summary.easy_questions: Easy questions focus on basic comprehension, asking students to identify explicit details and the main ideas presented in the text.
